definition: Breast composition with predominantly glandular tissue, which appears white on mammograms and can reduce the sensitivity of breast cancer screening.

name: Depressed Skull Fracture
definition: Skull fracture where a segment of bone is pushed inward, potentially causing intracranial injury, visible on CT or X-ray imaging.

name: Dermal Calcifications
definition: Radiological finding of calcium deposits within the dermal layer of the skin, often appearing as small, dense, white spots on imaging studies.

name: Dermal necrosis
definition: Pathological condition of skin tissue death, appearing as areas of decreased density or signal intensity on radiological imaging.

name: Dermoid cyst
definition: Benign congenital tumor containing developmental tissue elements, typically appearing as a well-defined cystic lesion on imaging studies.

name: Desmoid Tumors
definition: Rare, locally aggressive soft tissue tumors that appear as infiltrative masses on imaging, often with ill-defined margins.

name: Deterministic effects (skin burns/injury)
definition: Radiation-induced tissue damage with predictable, threshold-dependent effects on human tissues, observable through various imaging modalities.

name: Devascularization
definition: Radiological finding of reduced or absent blood supply to a specific tissue or organ, potentially indicating ischemia or tissue damage.

name: Developmental dermoids/gliomas
definition: Congenital lesions arising from abnormal embryological development, typically appearing as complex, mixed-density masses on imaging studies.

name: Developmental Dysplasia of Hip (DDH)
definition: Congenital hip joint condition characterized by abnormal development of the hip socket, visible on radiographic imaging as altered joint morphology.

name: Developmental Venous Anomaly (DVA)
definition: Benign cerebrovascular malformation consisting of dilated, tortuous veins, typically appearing as a focal area of increased vascularity on imaging studies.

name: Device Malfunction (e.g., pacemaker reset)
definition: Unexpected failure or malfunction of an implanted medical device, such as a pacemaker, which can be detected through imaging studies. Radiological evaluation helps assess device integrity and potential complications.

name: Device malfunctions (pacemakers, cochlear implants)
definition: Unexpected failure or malfunction of implantable medical devices like pacemakers or cochlear implants, which can be identified through radiological imaging techniques. Imaging helps diagnose structural or functional device issues.

name: DEXA
definition: Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry, a low-radiation imaging technique used to measure bone mineral density and assess risk of osteoporosis. Commonly used for bone health screening.

name: Diabetes
definition: Metabolic disorder characterized by elevated blood glucose levels, which can cause various radiological findings in multiple organ systems. Imaging can reveal complications like vascular changes, kidney alterations, and tissue damage.

name: Diabetes Insipidus
definition: Rare hormonal disorder causing excessive thirst and urination due to insufficient antidiuretic hormone, which can have associated radiological manifestations in the pituitary and hypothalamic regions.

name: Diabetic Foot Infection
definition: Serious soft tissue infection in diabetic patients affecting the foot, often visible through radiological imaging showing soft tissue changes, gas formation, or bone involvement.

name: Diabetic Mastopathy (DMP) / Sclerosing Lymphocytic Lobulitis
definition: Rare breast condition characterized by fibrotic changes in breast tissue, typically identified through mammographic and ultrasound imaging showing distinctive architectural distortions.

name: Dialysis Associated Steal Syndrome (DASS)
definition: Vascular complication occurring in dialysis patients, characterized by reduced blood flow in the affected limb, which can be evaluated through vascular imaging techniques.

name: Diaphragmatic Eventration
definition: Abnormal elevation or displacement of the diaphragm, which can be detected through chest radiographs and CT imaging, potentially indicating underlying respiratory or neurological conditions.

name: Diastatic Skull Fracture
definition: Skull fracture involving separation of bone segments without complete disruption, typically identified through CT or X-ray imaging showing linear fracture patterns.

name: Diastematomyelia
definition: Rare congenital spinal cord malformation characterized by longitudinal splitting of the spinal cord, typically diagnosed through MRI revealing the distinctive anatomical abnormality.

name: Diastolic Dysfunction
definition: Impaired cardiac relaxation and filling during the diastolic phase, detectable through echocardiography and cardiac imaging techniques showing abnormal ventricular compliance.

name: Diastrophic Dysplasia
definition: Rare genetic disorder affecting bone and cartilage development, characterized by distinctive skeletal radiographic findings including short limbs and joint abnormalities.

name: Dieulafoy Lesion
definition: Rare vascular lesion characterized by a large, aberrant blood vessel in the gastrointestinal tract, potentially identifiable through endoscopic or angiographic imaging.

name: Differentiated Thyroid Cancer (DTC) - Follicular
definition: Thyroid cancer originating from follicular cells with distinct follicular cell architecture, typically identified through ultrasound, CT, and nuclear medicine imaging.

name: Differentiated Thyroid Cancer (DTC) - Papillary
definition: Thyroid cancer characterized by papillary growth pattern, typically detected through ultrasound, CT, and nuclear medicine imaging showing characteristic architectural features.

name: Diffuse Astrocytoma (Low-Grade)
definition: A slow-growing, infiltrative brain tumor originating from astrocytes, typically appearing as a diffuse, low-grade lesion on imaging. Radiologically characterized by relatively uniform signal intensity and minimal mass effect.

name: Diffuse Axonal Injury (DAI)
definition: A severe brain injury involving widespread damage to white matter axons, typically resulting from rotational or acceleration-deceleration forces. Radiologically characterized by multiple small hemorrhagic lesions in white matter tracts.

name: Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH)
definition: A systemic spinal condition characterized by extensive new bone formation along the anterior longitudinal ligament of the spine, without significant inflammatory changes. Radiologically appears as continuous, flowing ossification along vertebral bodies.

name: Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma (DIPG)
definition: An aggressive, infiltrative brainstem tumor occurring primarily in children, with poor prognosis. Radiologically appears as an expansile, infiltrative lesion involving the pons with minimal contrast enhancement.

name: Diffuse Intrinsic Pontine Glioma (DIPG) / Diffuse Midline Glioma (DMG), H3 K27-altered
definition: A specific subtype of diffuse midline glioma characterized by H3 K27 mutation, typically occurring in children with extremely poor prognosis. Radiologically similar to standard DIPG with characteristic brainstem involvement.

name: Dilated collecting system
definition: A radiographic finding of an enlarged or abnormally expanded renal collecting system, often indicating obstruction or urinary tract pathology.

name: Dilated perivascular spaces
definition: Enlarged fluid-filled spaces surrounding blood vessels in the brain, often seen as incidental findings on neuroimaging. Typically appear as small, well-defined lucent spaces adjacent to blood vessels.

name: Disc fragment
definition: A piece of intervertebral disc material that has separated from the main disc structure, potentially causing nerve root compression. Radiologically appears as a focal disc material displacement.

name: Disc herniation
definition: Protrusion or displacement of intervertebral disc material beyond its normal anatomical boundaries, potentially causing nerve root compression. Radiologically characterized by disc material extending beyond vertebral margins.

name: Discitis
definition: An inflammatory condition of the intervertebral disc space, often associated with infection. Radiologically shows disc space narrowing, end plate irregularity, and potential adjacent vertebral body involvement.

name: Discoid Meniscus
definition: A congenital variant of the meniscus characterized by an abnormal, disc-like shape instead of the typical C-shaped configuration. Radiologically appears as a thickened, more horizontal meniscus.

name: Dislocation (THA)
definition: Displacement of the femoral head from the acetabulum in total hip arthroplasty, potentially indicating prosthetic failure. Radiologically characterized by abnormal positioning of hip prosthesis components.

name: Dissection
definition: Separation or tear of a blood vessel wall, potentially causing blood to flow between vessel wall layers. Radiologically identified through characteristic imaging findings of vessel wall disruption.

name: Dissection / Thrombosis
definition: Simultaneous occurrence of vessel dissection and thrombosis, potentially indicating complex vascular pathology. Radiologically shows both vessel wall disruption and intraluminal thrombus formation.

name: Disseminated Intravascular Coagulopathy (DIC)
definition: A severe systemic coagulation disorder characterized by widespread blood clot formation and subsequent bleeding. Radiologically may show multiple small vessel thromboses and potential hemorrhagic complications.

name: Distal Cholangiocarcinoma
definition: A malignant tumor located in the distal portion of the bile duct, often causing biliary obstruction. Radiologically characterized by focal bile duct wall thickening and potential mass effect.

name: Distal Radioulnar Joint (DRUJ) Instability
definition: A condition characterized by abnormal movement or subluxation of the distal radioulnar joint, often detected through imaging techniques like X-ray or MRI. This instability can result in pain, reduced range of motion, and potential joint dysfunction.

name: Distal radioulnar joint instability
definition: A condition characterized by abnormal movement or subluxation of the distal radioulnar joint, often detected through imaging techniques like X-ray or MRI. This instability can result in pain, reduced range of motion, and potential joint dysfunction.

name: Distal Radius Fracture (Colles' fracture)
definition: A common fracture of the distal radius, typically occurring from a fall on an outstretched hand. Radiographic findings include dorsal angulation, displacement, and potential comminution of the distal radius.

name: Distant Metastases (Bone)
definition: Spread of cancer cells to bone tissue, typically identified through radiographic techniques like CT, MRI, or bone scans. Metastatic lesions appear as osteolytic or osteoblastic changes in bone structures.

name: Distant Metastases (Liver)
definition: Spread of cancer cells to liver tissue, detected through imaging modalities such as CT, MRI, or PET scans. Liver metastases typically appear as multiple hypodense or heterogeneous lesions within the liver parenchyma.

name: Distant Metastases (Lung)
definition: Spread of cancer cells to lung tissue, identified through chest radiography, CT, or PET scans. Lung metastases typically present as multiple nodular or ground-glass opacities throughout lung fields.

name: Diverticular Bleed
definition: Active bleeding from diverticula in the gastrointestinal tract, typically identified through CT angiography or nuclear medicine studies. Radiographic findings may include contrast extravasation or active bleeding sites.

name: Diverticulitis
definition: Inflammatory condition of diverticula in the colon, characterized by radiographic findings of bowel wall thickening, pericolonic fat stranding, and potential abscess formation on CT scans.

name: Diverticulosis
definition: Presence of diverticula in the colon without active inflammation, typically identified incidentally on CT or colonoscopy. Radiographic findings include multiple outpouchings of the colonic wall.

name: DMSA Scan
definition: A nuclear medicine renal scan using technetium-99m dimercaptosuccinic acid to evaluate kidney structure and function. Primarily used to assess renal scarring and pediatric urinary tract infections.

name: DNET (Dysembryoplastic Neuroepithelial Tumor)
definition: A rare, low-grade glial tumor typically found in the cerebral cortex, characterized by distinctive radiographic features on MRI including mixed signal intensity and cortical involvement.

name: Dolichoectasia
definition: Abnormal dilation and elongation of blood vessels, typically identified on vascular imaging studies like CT angiography or MR angiography. Often affects cerebral or intracranial vessels.

name: DOMS
definition: Delayed onset muscle soreness, a condition characterized by muscle pain and stiffness following unaccustomed exercise, typically not directly visualized on radiographic studies.

name: Doppler Ultrasound
definition: An ultrasound technique that uses sound waves to measure blood flow velocity and direction in blood vessels. Helps assess vascular conditions, blood flow restrictions, and potential blockages.

name: Double Adenoma
definition: Presence of two distinct adenomas, typically identified in endocrine or other organ systems through imaging techniques like CT or MRI. Often requires correlation with clinical and pathological findings.

name: Double bubble sign
definition: A radiographic sign showing two adjacent fluid-filled structures resembling bubbles, typically associated with duodenal atresia in pediatric imaging.

name: Double duct sign
definition: A radiographic finding of simultaneous dilation of both pancreatic and bile ducts, often indicating pancreatic or biliary pathology.

name: Down syndrome
definition: Genetic chromosomal disorder characterized by distinctive radiographic features including specific craniofacial morphology, skeletal abnormalities, and potential cardiac malformations.

name: Drug-induced coma
definition: Medically induced unconscious state resulting from pharmacological intervention, typically monitored through clinical assessment and potentially neuroimaging techniques.

name: Drug-Induced Liver Injury (DILI)
definition: Liver damage caused by medication, detectable through imaging studies showing hepatic changes such as inflammation, steatosis, or structural abnormalities. Radiological findings can help diagnose and monitor drug-induced liver injury.

name: Drug-induced Parkinsonism
definition: Medication-induced movement disorder mimicking Parkinson's disease, characterized by extrapyramidal symptoms visible through neuroimaging studies. Radiology can help differentiate drug-induced from idiopathic Parkinsonism.

name: Drug-induced pneumonitis
definition: Medication-induced lung inflammation detectable through chest radiographs and CT scans, showing diffuse or focal infiltrates, ground-glass opacities, or interstitial changes.

name: DSA
definition: Digital subtraction angiography, an X-ray imaging technique that provides detailed visualization of blood vessels after contrast injection. Allows dynamic assessment of vascular structures and blood flow.

name: Duct Ectasia
definition: Abnormal dilation of a duct system, visible through imaging studies showing widened ductal structures. Radiological assessment helps evaluate underlying causes and potential complications.

name: Ductal Carcinoma In Situ (DCIS)
definition: Non-invasive breast cancer confined to milk ducts, detectable through mammography and breast imaging showing microcalcifications or architectural distortions within ductal structures.

name: Ductal Ectasia
definition: Abnormal dilation of a duct system, visible through imaging studies showing widened ductal structures. Radiological assessment helps evaluate underlying causes and potential complications.

name: Ductal Obstruction
definition: Blockage or narrowing of a ductal system, identifiable through imaging techniques revealing interruption of normal ductal flow or structural changes.

name: Ductal Stones
definition: Calcified deposits within ductal systems, detectable through various imaging modalities showing radiopaque structures within ducts.

name: Ductal Stricture
definition: Narrowing of a ductal system, visible through imaging studies showing reduced ductal diameter and potential obstruction.

name: Dumping syndrome
definition: Gastrointestinal disorder characterized by rapid gastric emptying, potentially showing radiological signs of altered digestive tract motility and fluid redistribution.

name: Duodenal Adenocarcinoma
definition: Malignant tumor of the duodenum, detectable through cross-sectional imaging showing mass lesions, wall thickening, and potential metastatic spread.

name: Duodenal atresia
definition: Congenital absence or narrowing of duodenal lumen, identifiable through pediatric imaging studies showing interrupted intestinal continuity.

name: Duodenal Atresia (DA)
definition: Congenital absence or narrowing of duodenal lumen, identifiable through pediatric imaging studies showing interrupted intestinal continuity.

name: Duodenal Diverticulum
definition: Outpouching or pouch-like projection from duodenal wall, detectable through contrast studies or cross-sectional imaging showing focal outward bulging.

name: Duodenal Trauma (Rupture)
definition: Severe duodenal injury potentially causing rupture, identifiable through emergency imaging showing fluid collections, wall discontinuity, or extraluminal air.

name: Duplex Collecting System
definition: A congenital kidney anomaly where the collecting system is duplicated, with two separate ureters draining a single kidney. Radiologically characterized by distinct collecting systems visible on imaging studies.

name: Duplex Ultrasound
definition: An ultrasound technique combining grayscale imaging with color Doppler to evaluate blood vessel structure and blood flow. Provides comprehensive assessment of vascular anatomy and hemodynamics.

name: Duplicated collecting system
definition: A congenital kidney anomaly where the collecting system is duplicated, with two separate ureters draining a single kidney. Radiologically characterized by distinct collecting systems visible on imaging studies.

name: Dural arteriovenous fistula (dAVF)
definition: An abnormal vascular connection between dural arteries and veins in the brain, causing potential hemorrhage or neurological symptoms. Radiologically identified through angiography or MRI.

name: Dural Arteriovenous Fistulas
definition: An abnormal vascular connection between dural arteries and veins in the brain, causing potential hemorrhage or neurological symptoms. Radiologically identified through angiography or MRI.

name: Dural Ectasia
definition: A pathological enlargement and stretching of the dura mater, often associated with connective tissue disorders. Radiologically observed as abnormal dural expansion on imaging studies.

name: Dural metastases
definition: Cancerous spread of tumors to the dural membranes surrounding the brain or spinal cord. Radiologically detected through contrast-enhanced MRI or CT scans.

name: Dural Sinus Thrombosis
definition: A blood clot formation within the venous sinuses of the brain's dural membrane. Radiologically diagnosed through MRI venography or CT venography.

name: DVT
definition: A blood clot formation within a deep vein, typically in the legs. Radiologically identified through ultrasound, CT venography, or MR venography.

name: DXA
definition: Dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry, a low-radiation imaging technique used to measure bone mineral density and assess risk of osteoporosis. Commonly used for bone health screening.

name: Dysembryoplastic Neuroepithelial Tumor (DNET)
definition: A rare, benign neuroglial tumor typically found in the cerebral cortex. Radiologically characterized by specific imaging features on MRI.

name: Dysgenesis/Agenesis of the Corpus Callosum (ACC)
definition: A congenital malformation involving partial or complete absence of the corpus callosum. Radiologically diagnosed through brain MRI or CT imaging.

name: Dysplastic nodule
definition: An abnormal liver lesion often associated with chronic liver disease. Radiologically observed as a nodular change in liver parenchyma.

name: Dystrophic Calcification
definition: Abnormal calcium deposits in soft tissues, often indicating previous injury or degenerative processes. Radiologically identified as calcified areas on imaging studies.

name: Early IUP below discriminatory zone
definition: An early intrauterine pregnancy detected below the ultrasound discriminatory zone, requiring careful radiological evaluation.

name: Ebstein Anomaly
definition: A congenital heart defect involving abnormal development of the tricuspid valve. Radiologically characterized by specific cardiac structural changes on imaging.

name: ECG-gated CTA
definition: A cardiac computed tomography angiography technique synchronized with the electrocardiogram to capture detailed heart and coronary artery images during specific cardiac cycle phases.

name: Echinococcal cyst
definition: A parasitic cyst caused by the Echinococcus tapeworm, typically found in liver or other organs. Radiologically identified through characteristic imaging features on CT or ultrasound.

name: Echocardiogram
definition: A non-invasive ultrasound examination of the heart that uses sound waves to create real-time images of cardiac structure and function. Evaluates heart chambers, valves, and blood flow.

name: Echocardiography
definition: The medical technique of using ultrasound to create images of the heart's structure and function. Provides detailed visualization of cardiac anatomy and hemodynamics.

name: Echocardiography, Cardiac Catheterization
definition: A combined diagnostic approach involving cardiac catheterization and echocardiography to comprehensively evaluate cardiac structure, function, and hemodynamics.

name: Ectasia
definition: Abnormal dilation or expansion of a tubular structure or organ, visible on imaging as localized widening. Radiologists assess ectasia to evaluate potential underlying pathological conditions.

name: Ectopic Kidney
definition: Congenital malposition of a kidney located outside its normal anatomical position in the retroperitoneal space. Radiographic imaging helps determine the kidney's location and potential associated anomalies.

name: Ectopic pregnancy
definition: Pregnancy implanted outside the uterine cavity, most commonly in the fallopian tube. Radiologists use ultrasound and CT to diagnose and assess potential rupture or complications.

name: Ectopic Thyroid
definition: Thyroid tissue located in an abnormal anatomical location, typically identified through cross-sectional imaging. Radiologists evaluate its position, size, and potential functional characteristics.

name: Ectopic Thyroid Tissue
definition: Thyroid tissue found in an atypical location outside the normal thyroid gland anatomical position. Imaging helps characterize its location, extent, and potential clinical significance.

name: Edema
definition: Abnormal fluid accumulation in tissues, appearing as increased soft tissue density or signal intensity on radiographic imaging. Radiologists assess edema's distribution, severity, and potential underlying causes.

name: Edge Loading (THA)
definition: Radiographic finding in total hip arthroplasty where prosthetic component loading occurs primarily at the peripheral edge of the implant. Imaging helps assess potential mechanical stress and implant longevity.

name: Egg on a string
definition: A radiographic appearance of a thin, elongated structure resembling an egg suspended on a string, typically seen in certain gastrointestinal or esophageal conditions.

name: EGJ Outflow Obstruction
definition: Radiographic evidence of obstruction at the esophagogastric junction, typically identified through contrast studies or endoscopic imaging. Evaluates potential mechanical or functional barriers to esophageal emptying.

name: Elbow Dislocation
definition: Displacement of the elbow joint surfaces, visible on radiographic imaging as abnormal bone alignment. Radiologists assess joint displacement, associated soft tissue injuries, and potential complications.

name: Elbow effusion
definition: Abnormal fluid accumulation within the elbow joint space, identifiable on radiographic imaging as increased soft tissue density or signal intensity. Helps evaluate potential inflammatory or traumatic conditions.

name: Embolic Disease
definition: Radiographic evidence of blood vessel obstruction by emboli, typically identified through CT, MRI, or angiographic studies. Helps assess location, extent, and potential vascular compromise.

name: Embryonal carcinoma
definition: Malignant testicular tumor composed of primitive germ cells, characterized by distinct radiographic features. Imaging helps evaluate tumor size, location, and potential metastatic spread.

name: Embryonal Tumors (formerly PNET)
definition: Malignant tumors originating from embryonic tissue, typically found in pediatric populations. Radiologists use imaging to characterize tumor location, size, and potential metastatic involvement.

name: Emphysema
definition: Chronic lung condition characterized by abnormal air space enlargement, visible on chest radiographs as increased lung lucency and reduced vascular markings. Helps assess lung structural changes.

name: Emphysematous Cholecystitis
definition: Severe inflammatory gallbladder condition with gas formation, identified on radiographic imaging as gas within the gallbladder wall or lumen. Indicates potential serious infectious process.

name: Emphysematous Gastritis
definition: A rare and severe inflammatory condition of the stomach wall characterized by gas-forming bacteria causing pneumatosis of the gastric wall. Radiographic findings include gas within the gastric wall and potential perforation.

name: Emphysematous Pyelonephritis
definition: A severe necrotizing infection of the kidney characterized by gas formation within the renal parenchyma and collecting system. CT imaging reveals gas bubbles within the kidney and potential perinephric extension.

name: Empty Sella Syndrome (ESS)
definition: A radiological condition where the sella turcica appears partially or completely empty due to pituitary gland flattening or atrophy. Imaging shows an enlarged, partially filled or empty sella turcica.

name: Empyema
definition: An inflammatory condition with pus accumulation in the pleural space, typically seen as a fluid collection with complex echogenicity on imaging. Radiographs and CT scans reveal pleural fluid with potential loculations.

name: Encephalitis
definition: Inflammation of the brain parenchyma caused by viral, bacterial, or autoimmune processes. Imaging reveals brain swelling, potential hemorrhage, and focal areas of inflammation on MRI and CT.

name: Encephalitis (HSV)
definition: A viral brain infection caused by herpes simplex virus, characterized by temporal lobe involvement and potential hemorrhagic necrosis. MRI shows characteristic temporal lobe signal changes and potential hemorrhagic transformation.

name: Encephalomalacia
definition: Localized softening and liquefactive necrosis of brain tissue due to injury or infarction. Imaging reveals focal areas of brain tissue destruction with characteristic signal changes on MRI.

name: Enchondroma
definition: A benign cartilage tumor typically found in bones, appearing as a well-defined, lobulated radiolucent lesion on radiographs. Characterized by mature cartilage within the medullary cavity of bones.

name: End-Stage Liver Disease (ESLD)
definition: Advanced liver disease with significant structural and functional impairment. Imaging shows liver cirrhosis, nodular liver surface, and potential portal hypertension complications.

name: End-stage Osteoarthritis
definition: Advanced degenerative joint disease with complete cartilage loss and significant joint space narrowing. Radiographs show severe joint destruction, osteophyte formation, and subchondral sclerosis.

name: End-Stage Renal Disease (ESRD)
definition: Complete or near-complete kidney failure requiring dialysis or transplantation. Imaging shows small, contracted kidneys with reduced parenchymal volume and potential vascular calcifications.

name: Endocarditis
definition: Infection of the heart's inner lining and valves, characterized by vegetations visible on echocardiography and potential valve destruction. Imaging reveals vegetation, valve thickening, and potential abscess formation.

name: Endolymphatic Sac Tumor (ELST)
definition: A rare, slow-growing tumor of the endolymphatic sac in the temporal bone. Imaging shows a destructive lesion in the petrous apex with potential intracranial extension.

name: Endometrial Cancer
definition: Malignant tumor originating in the uterine endometrial lining. Imaging reveals endometrial thickening, irregular margins, and potential myometrial invasion.

name: Endometrial Hyperplasia
definition: Abnormal proliferation of endometrial glands leading to uterine lining thickening. Imaging shows increased endometrial thickness and potential cystic changes.

name: Endometrioma
definition: A type of ovarian cyst containing endometrial tissue, appearing as a complex cyst with characteristic low-density fluid and thick walls on imaging. Typically appears as a homogeneous, low-density mass with potential internal echogenicity on ultrasound and CT.

name: Endometriosis
definition: A condition where endometrial-like tissue grows outside the uterus, often visible on imaging as implants, adhesions, or cysts in the pelvis and abdomen. Radiological findings may include ovarian endometriomas, peritoneal implants, and potential associated inflammatory changes.

name: Endometritis
definition: Inflammation of the endometrium, typically appearing on imaging as thickened endometrial lining with potential fluid collection or abnormal enhancement. Ultrasound and CT can reveal uterine wall irregularities and inflammatory changes.

name: Endoscopy
definition: A medical procedure using a flexible tube with a camera to visually examine internal organs or body cavities. Allows direct visualization and potential diagnostic or therapeutic interventions.

name: Enhancing Lesion (mimicked by artifact)
definition: A lesion that demonstrates increased signal intensity or contrast uptake on imaging studies, which can be challenging to differentiate from artifacts. Careful evaluation of morphology, location, and enhancement characteristics is crucial for accurate interpretation.

name: Enhancing renal mass
definition: A radiographic finding of a mass within the kidney that demonstrates increased signal intensity or contrast enhancement, potentially indicating a tumor or lesion.

name: Enteropathic arthritis
definition: A type of inflammatory arthritis associated with inflammatory bowel diseases, characterized by radiographic findings of joint inflammation and potential bone erosions. Imaging may reveal symmetric or asymmetric joint involvement with periarticular osteopenia.

name: Enteropathic Arthritis (IBD-associated)
definition: Joint inflammation directly linked to inflammatory bowel diseases like Crohn's and ulcerative colitis, presenting radiographically with symmetric or asymmetric joint involvement and potential bone erosions. Imaging can reveal periarticular osteopenia and joint space narrowing.

name: EOB-MRI
definition: A specialized magnetic resonance imaging technique using hepatobiliary contrast agents to enhance liver and biliary system visualization. Provides detailed assessment of liver lesions and biliary structures.

name: Eosinophilic fasciitis
definition: A rare inflammatory disorder characterized by progressive skin thickening and fascia inflammation, typically appearing on imaging as soft tissue thickening and potential fascial enhancement. MRI can reveal characteristic fascial edema and soft tissue changes.

name: Ependymoma
definition: A primary central nervous system tumor arising from ependymal cells, typically appearing on imaging as a well-defined intraventricular or spinal canal mass with heterogeneous enhancement. MRI reveals characteristic signal characteristics and potential calcifications.

name: Epicardial CAD
definition: Coronary artery disease affecting the outer layer of the heart's blood vessels, visible on cardiac imaging as potential wall thickening, calcifications, or stenotic changes in the epicardial coronary arteries.

name: Epidermal Inclusion Cysts (EIC)/Sebaceous Cysts
definition: Benign skin cysts containing keratin debris, appearing on imaging as well-defined, round, hypoechoic or low-density lesions with potential internal echogenic or calcific components.

name: Epidermoid Cyst
definition: A benign cutaneous cyst lined with squamous epithelium, typically appearing on imaging as a well-circumscribed, round lesion with potential internal calcifications or keratin debris.

name: Epididymitis
definition: Inflammation of the epididymis, typically appearing on ultrasound as a swollen, heterogeneous epididymal structure with increased vascularity and potential fluid collection.

name: Epidural Abscess
definition: A serious infection located in the epidural space, typically appearing on imaging as a complex fluid collection with potential enhancement and surrounding soft tissue inflammation. MRI is particularly sensitive in detecting epidural abscess extent and characteristics.

name: Epidural hematoma
definition: Bleeding between the skull and dura mater, typically appearing on CT as a lens-shaped, biconvex extra-axial hemorrhage often associated with skull fractures. Characterized by mass effect and potential midline shift.

name: Epidural Hematoma (EDH)
definition: A traumatic brain hemorrhage located between the skull and dura mater, typically presenting on CT as a biconvex, lens-shaped extra-axial collection with potential significant mass effect.

name: Epiglottitis
definition: Acute inflammation of the epiglottis characterized by swelling and potential airway obstruction. Radiographic findings include soft tissue swelling and edema of the epiglottic region.

name: Epiglottitis (Supraglottitis)
definition: Inflammation of the supraglottic region of the larynx, causing significant soft tissue swelling. Imaging typically reveals epiglottic edema and potential airway compromise.

name: Epilation
definition: Loss of hair or hair removal, often observed in radiation therapy or certain medical treatments. Radiological assessment may involve tracking hair loss patterns and associated skin changes.

name: Epilepsy
definition: Neurological disorder characterized by recurrent seizures. Radiological evaluation may include brain MRI or CT to identify underlying structural abnormalities.

name: Epiphrenic Diverticulum
definition: Rare esophageal outpouching located near the diaphragm. Radiographic diagnosis typically involves barium swallow or CT studies showing a focal diverticular projection.

name: Epiploic Appendagitis (EA)
definition: Inflammatory condition affecting the epiploic appendages of the colon. CT imaging reveals characteristic focal fat stranding and peripheral inflammation.

name: Epithelioid Sarcoma
definition: Rare soft tissue sarcoma with distinctive epithelioid cellular morphology. Radiological assessment involves CT and MRI to evaluate tumor extent and characteristics.

name: ERCP
definition: Endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP) is a diagnostic and therapeutic procedure that combines endoscopy and fluoroscopy to examine the bile and pancreatic ducts. It allows visualization and intervention in the biliary and pancreatic systems using contrast and real-time X-ray imaging.

name: ERCP Complications
definition: Potential adverse events following endoscopic retrograde cholangiopancreatography (ERCP). Radiological evaluation includes identifying complications like pancreatitis, perforation, or bleeding.

name: Erosion
definition: Superficial loss of tissue surface, often visible on radiographic imaging as a focal defect or discontinuity in tissue integrity.

name: Erythema
definition: Skin redness indicating inflammation, potentially visible on radiographic studies as soft tissue changes or increased contrast enhancement.

name: Esophageal Atresia
definition: Congenital malformation where the esophagus does not develop properly, ending in a blind pouch. Radiographic diagnosis involves contrast studies and cross-sectional imaging.

name: Esophageal Atresia (EA) with Tracheoesophageal Fistula (TEF)
definition: Complex congenital anomaly involving incomplete esophageal development and abnormal connection between esophagus and trachea. Radiological assessment requires detailed anatomical evaluation.

name: Esophageal cancer
definition: Malignant tumor of the esophageal mucosa with potential for metastasis. Radiological staging involves CT, PET, and endoscopic ultrasound to assess tumor extent.

name: Esophageal Narrowing
definition: Pathological reduction in esophageal lumen diameter, potentially due to strictures, tumors, or inflammatory conditions. Diagnosed through contrast studies and cross-sectional imaging.

name: Esophageal perforation with mediastinal air
definition: Serious condition involving esophageal wall rupture with air in the mediastinum. Radiographic findings include pneumomediastinum and potential contrast extravasation.

name: Esophageal Ring
definition: A circumferential narrowing of the esophageal lumen, typically visible on radiographic imaging as a ring-like constriction. Can be congenital or acquired, and may cause difficulty in swallowing.

name: Esophageal Stricture
definition: A localized narrowing of the esophageal lumen caused by scarring, inflammation, or other pathological processes. Radiographically appears as a segment of narrowed esophageal diameter.

name: Esophageal Tumor
definition: An abnormal growth within the esophageal wall or lumen, detectable through various radiographic techniques such as CT, MRI, or barium studies. Can be benign or malignant.

name: Esophageal Varices
definition: Abnormally dilated and tortuous veins in the lower esophagus, typically seen in patients with portal hypertension. Radiographically appear as tortuous, dilated vascular structures.

name: Esophageal Web
definition: A thin, membranous tissue projection in the esophageal lumen, typically seen as a thin, smooth linear opacity on radiographic imaging. Can cause intermittent dysphagia.

name: Essential hypertension
definition: Chronic high blood pressure without a specific identifiable cause, characterized by persistently elevated blood pressure readings. Radiological findings may include vascular changes and end-organ effects.

name: Essential Tremor
definition: A neurological disorder characterized by rhythmic, involuntary shaking, typically of the hands. Radiological studies are often used to rule out other neurological conditions.

name: Essential Tremor (ET)
definition: A neurological disorder characterized by rhythmic, involuntary shaking, typically of the hands. Radiological studies are often used to rule out other neurological conditions.

name: Esthesioneuroblastoma
definition: A rare malignant tumor originating in the olfactory epithelium, typically located in the nasal cavity and cribriform plate. Radiographically characterized by complex soft tissue masses with potential intracranial extension.

name: Ewing Sarcoma
definition: A rare type of bone cancer primarily affecting children and young adults, typically occurring in long bones and pelvis. Radiographically appears as a destructive bone lesion with periosteal reaction.

name: Ex-vacuo ventriculomegaly
definition: A form of brain ventricular enlargement resulting from significant brain tissue loss, characterized by disproportionately large ventricles compared to brain parenchyma.

name: Exocrine/Endocrine Insufficiency
definition: A condition where pancreatic glands fail to produce adequate digestive enzymes or hormones, potentially affecting both exocrine and endocrine functions. Radiological findings may include pancreatic atrophy or calcifications.

name: Exogenous thyroid hormone use
definition: Medical use of synthetic thyroid hormones to manage thyroid disorders, which can be detected through various imaging studies showing thyroid gland characteristics.

name: Extracranial Vertebral Artery Dissection
definition: A traumatic or spontaneous tear in the vertebral artery wall outside the skull, potentially causing blood flow disruption. Radiographically identified through vascular imaging techniques.

name: Extradural meningeal cyst without nerve fibers (Type I)
definition: A specific type of meningeal cyst located outside the dura mater, characterized by the absence of neural tissue. Typically identified through neuroimaging studies.

name: Extramammary pain
definition: Pain occurring outside the breast tissue, which may be evaluated through various imaging techniques to rule out underlying pathological conditions. Radiological assessment helps identify potential sources of pain not directly related to mammary structures.

name: Extrapontine Myelinolysis (EPM)
definition: A neurological condition characterized by demyelination of brain regions outside the pons, typically seen on MRI as symmetric signal changes. Radiological findings include potential brain lesions and white matter abnormalities.

name: Extravasation
definition: Abnormal leakage of fluid or contrast material from blood vessels into surrounding tissue, detectable through various radiological imaging techniques. Typically observed as unintended spread of contrast during diagnostic procedures.

name: Extrinsic Compression
definition: External pressure or force causing narrowing or displacement of anatomical structures, visible through imaging studies. Radiological evaluation helps identify the source and extent of compression.

name: Extrinsic compression of renal artery
definition: External pressure or obstruction affecting the renal artery's blood flow, identifiable through vascular imaging techniques like CT angiography or MR angiography. Can result in reduced arterial patency.

name: Extrinsic compression of renal vein
definition: External pressure or obstruction impacting the renal vein's blood flow, detectable through venographic imaging studies. Can lead to venous congestion or altered hemodynamics.

name: Facet Arthropathy
definition: Degenerative changes affecting the facet joints of the spine, characterized by joint space narrowing, osteophyte formation, and potential articular surface irregularities. Radiologically identified through X-ray, CT, or MRI.

name: Facet Dislocation
definition: Complete displacement or abnormal separation of vertebral facet joints, typically identified through radiographic imaging. Can indicate significant spinal trauma or instability.

name: Facet Joint Osteoarthritis
definition: Progressive degenerative changes in the facet joints of the spine, characterized by cartilage breakdown, joint space narrowing, and potential bone proliferation. Diagnosed through various radiological techniques.

name: Facet subluxation
definition: Partial displacement or abnormal movement of facet joints, detectable through radiographic imaging. Indicates potential spinal instability or ligamentous injury.

name: Facetogenic Pain
definition: Pain originating from the facet joints of the spine, often identified through correlative imaging and clinical assessment. Radiological studies help exclude other potential pain sources.

name: Facial Nerve Canal Disruption
definition: Disruption or damage to the facial nerve canal, identifiable through high-resolution CT or MRI imaging. Can indicate traumatic injury or pathological changes.

name: Facial Nerve Injury (Post-traumatic Neuritis)
definition: Traumatic damage to the facial nerve, detectable through advanced neuroimaging techniques. Radiological assessment helps evaluate the extent and location of nerve injury.

name: Failed Back Surgery Syndrome (FBSS)
definition: Persistent pain and functional limitations following spinal surgery, characterized by complex radiological findings. Imaging helps assess potential surgical complications or ongoing pathological processes.

name: False Negative Breast Cancer
definition: A breast cancer case initially missed by radiological screening, highlighting potential limitations in imaging detection. Emphasizes the importance of comprehensive and multiple imaging modalities.

name: Familial Adenomatous Polyposis (FAP)
definition: Inherited genetic disorder characterized by numerous precancerous polyps in the colon and rectum, which can be visualized through colonoscopy and imaging studies. These polyps have a high risk of progressing to colorectal cancer.

name: Fat-poor AML
definition: A rare variant of angiomyolipoma with minimal or no visible fat content on radiological imaging, typically appearing as a solid renal mass with challenging differential diagnosis.

name: Fat-Poor Angiomyolipoma (AML)
definition: A rare variant of angiomyolipoma with minimal or no visible fat content on radiological imaging, typically appearing as a solid renal mass with challenging differential diagnosis.

name: Fat embolism syndrome
definition: A serious condition where fat globules enter the bloodstream and lodge in the lungs, causing respiratory distress and potentially visible pulmonary changes on chest imaging.

name: Fat Embolism Syndrome (FES)
definition: A serious condition where fat globules enter the bloodstream and lodge in the lungs, causing respiratory distress and potentially visible pulmonary changes on chest imaging.

name: Fat Necrosis
definition: Localized tissue death of fatty tissue, often appearing as calcified or inflammatory changes on radiological imaging, commonly seen in various body regions.

name: Fat Necrosis of the Breast
definition: Localized fatty tissue death in breast tissue, typically appearing as calcifications, oil cysts, or irregular masses on mammographic and ultrasound imaging.

name: Fat Necrosis/Oil Cysts/Scarring/Fibrosis
definition: Complex breast tissue changes involving fat necrosis, characterized by various radiological findings including cysts, scarring, and fibrotic changes on imaging studies.

name: Fatty Atrophy
definition: Progressive loss of fatty tissue volume in a specific anatomical region, often visible through comparative imaging studies showing reduced fat density.

name: Fatty Liver
definition: Accumulation of fat in liver cells, appearing as increased hepatic echogenicity on ultrasound and altered signal intensity on MRI, often associated with metabolic disorders.

name: FDG-PET/CT
definition: FDG-PET/CT is a molecular imaging technique combining fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) positron emission tomography with computed tomography. It provides metabolic and anatomical information, allowing detailed visualization of disease processes, particularly useful in oncology for cancer staging and treatment monitoring.

name: FDG PET/CT
definition: FDG PET/CT is a molecular imaging technique combining fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) positron emission tomography with computed tomography. It provides metabolic and anatomical information, allowing detailed visualization of disease processes, particularly useful in oncology for cancer staging and treatment monitoring.

name: Febrile Neutropenia (FUO)
definition: A clinical condition of fever and low neutrophil count, potentially indicating serious underlying infection, with radiological implications for monitoring potential complications.

name: Fecal peritonitis
definition: Severe abdominal infection resulting from bowel perforation, causing widespread inflammation and potentially visible free air or fluid on radiological imaging.

name: Femoral Acetabular Impingement (FAI)
definition: A hip joint condition characterized by abnormal bone morphology causing mechanical impingement, visible through detailed radiographic and CT imaging of the hip joint.

name: Femoral head AVN
definition: Avascular necrosis of the femoral head, characterized by bone death and potential structural collapse, typically identified through MRI and radiographic imaging.

name: Femoral Neck Fracture
definition: Fracture occurring at the neck of the femur, often seen in elderly patients, with specific radiographic classification and potential surgical intervention implications.

name: Femoroacetabular Impingement (FAI)
definition: A hip joint condition characterized by abnormal contact between the femoral head-neck junction and acetabular rim, causing mechanical impingement and potential cartilage damage. Radiologically identified through specific morphological changes in femoral or acetabular anatomy.

name: Ferromagnetic projectile injuries
definition: Traumatic injuries caused by metallic objects becoming magnetized and causing internal damage when exposed to strong magnetic fields, particularly in MRI environments. Radiological assessment involves identifying location and potential trajectory of metallic fragments.

name: Ferromagnetism
definition: A magnetic property where certain materials can be magnetized and attracted to magnetic fields, with significant implications for medical imaging and diagnostic procedures. Critically important in understanding MRI safety protocols.

name: Fetal CNS damage
definition: Structural and functional brain abnormalities occurring during fetal development, detectable through advanced neuroimaging techniques like fetal MRI. Encompasses various pathological changes affecting neural tissue.

name: Fetal Ventriculomegaly
definition: Abnormal enlargement of cerebral ventricles during fetal development, detected through ultrasound and fetal MRI. Indicates potential neurological complications or developmental disorders.

name: Fever of Unknown Origin (FUO)
definition: Persistent fever without an identifiable source, requiring comprehensive diagnostic imaging to investigate potential underlying conditions. Radiological evaluation involves systematic assessment of multiple organ systems.

name: Fibrin sheath formation
definition: Formation of fibrin coating around medical devices or within blood vessels, observable through imaging techniques. Represents a potential complication in interventional procedures.

name: Fibroadenoma
definition: Benign breast tumor composed of glandular and connective tissue, typically appearing as well-defined, smooth mass on mammographic and ultrasound imaging.

name: Fibroadenomas
definition: Benign breast tumor composed of glandular and connective tissue, typically appearing as well-defined, smooth mass on mammographic and ultrasound imaging.

name: Fibrocystic Change (FCC)
definition: Benign breast condition characterized by lumpy, nodular breast tissue with multiple cysts and fibrotic changes, typically identified through mammographic and ultrasound imaging.

name: Fibrocystic changes
definition: Benign breast condition characterized by lumpy, nodular breast tissue with multiple cysts and fibrotic changes, typically identified through mammographic and ultrasound imaging.

name: Fibrolamellar Carcinoma
definition: Rare primary liver tumor with distinct radiological characteristics, typically appearing as a well-demarcated lesion with specific imaging features distinguishing it from other hepatic neoplasms.

name: Fibromuscular Dysplasia
definition: Non-inflammatory vascular disease causing abnormal cell growth in arterial walls, characterized by distinctive radiological appearances of arterial stenosis and tortuosity.

name: Fibromuscular Dysplasia (FMD)
definition: Non-inflammatory vascular disease causing abnormal cell growth in arterial walls, characterized by distinctive radiological appearances of arterial stenosis and tortuosity.

name: Fibrosarcoma
definition: Malignant soft tissue tumor arising from fibrous tissue, characterized by specific radiological features including infiltrative growth pattern and distinct signal characteristics on MRI.

name: Fibrosing Mediastinitis
definition: A rare inflammatory condition characterized by extensive fibrosis and scarring in the mediastinum, causing progressive narrowing of blood vessels and airways. Radiologically, it presents as dense, extensive soft tissue masses in the mediastinal region.

name: Fibrosis
definition: Pathological process of excessive fibrous connective tissue formation in an organ or tissue, often resulting in reduced organ function and visible tissue hardening. In radiology, fibrosis appears as increased density and architectural distortion.

name: Fibrous Dysplasia
definition: A benign bone disorder where normal bone is replaced by fibrous tissue and immature bone, causing structural weakening and deformity. Radiographically characterized by ground-glass appearance and expansion of affected bone.

name: Figure 3 sign
definition: A radiographic sign depicting a configuration or appearance resembling the numeral 3, often observed in specific anatomical or pathological contexts.

name: Filling Defects in Renal Collecting System
definition: Abnormal areas within the renal collecting system that interrupt normal contrast or fluid flow, potentially indicating stones, tumors, or blood clots. Radiologically detected through CT, ultrasound, or contrast studies.

name: First-trimester pregnancy
definition: Early stage of pregnancy from conception to 12 weeks, characterized by embryonic development. Radiologically assessed through transvaginal ultrasound to confirm gestational sac, yolk sac, and embryonic cardiac activity.

name: Flat Epithelial Atypia (FEA)
definition: A microscopic breast lesion showing mild architectural and cytological changes in epithelial cells, often considered a precursor to potential breast pathology. Radiologically subtle and typically detected through detailed mammographic evaluation.

name: Flexor-pronator mass strain
definition: Soft tissue injury involving the flexor-pronator muscle group in the forearm, typically seen in athletes. Radiologically characterized by muscle edema, potential partial tears, and localized soft tissue swelling.

name: Flexor tenosynovitis
definition: Inflammatory condition of the tendon sheath causing thickening, fluid accumulation, and potential adhesions. Radiologically identified through ultrasound or MRI showing synovial thickening and fluid collection.

name: Fluid Collections
definition: Accumulation of fluid in various body spaces or tissues, detectable through imaging techniques. Radiologically assessed by density, location, and characteristics of fluid collections.

name: Fluid Collections (e.g., simple cyst)
definition: Benign, well-defined fluid-filled sac with uniform, anechoic appearance. Radiologically characterized by clear margins and absence of internal echogenicity or septations.

name: Fluid Overload
definition: Excessive fluid retention in the body, leading to edema and potential cardiovascular strain. Radiologically evident through increased soft tissue density, pleural effusions, and cardiac enlargement.

name: Fluoroscopy
definition: Fluoroscopy is a real-time X-ray imaging technique that allows continuous visualization of internal body structures in motion. It provides dynamic imaging of anatomical structures and is commonly used for diagnostic and interventional procedures.

name: Fluoroscopy (Esophagram)
definition: Fluoroscopic esophagram is a dynamic X-ray examination of the esophagus using contrast material to evaluate swallowing function, identify structural abnormalities, and assess potential pathologies in the esophageal region.

name: Fluoroscopy (stable), CT (unstable)
definition: This approach indicates using fluoroscopy for stable patients and CT for unstable patients, allowing appropriate imaging technique selection based on patient condition and clinical requirements.

name: Fluoroscopy (UGI)
definition: Upper gastrointestinal (UGI) fluoroscopy is a radiographic examination of the upper digestive tract using contrast material to evaluate the esophagus, stomach, and proximal small intestine for structural and functional abnormalities.

name: Fluoroscopy (Upper GI / Esophagram)
definition: Upper GI/Esophagram fluoroscopy is a dynamic X-ray examination of the esophagus and upper gastrointestinal tract using contrast material to evaluate swallowing function and identify structural abnormalities.

name: Fluoroscopy (Upper GI Series)
definition: Upper GI Series is a comprehensive fluoroscopic examination of the esophagus, stomach, and proximal small intestine using contrast material to assess structural and functional characteristics of the upper digestive tract.

name: Focal Cortical Dysplasia
definition: Developmental malformation of cerebral cortex characterized by abnormal neuronal organization and potential epileptogenesis. Radiologically detected through MRI showing cortical thickening, abnormal gyral patterns.

name: Focal Cortical Dysplasia (FCD)
definition: Developmental malformation of cerebral cortex characterized by abnormal neuronal organization and potential epileptogenesis. Radiologically detected through MRI showing cortical thickening, abnormal gyral patterns.

name: Focal Fibrosis
definition: Localized area of fibrous tissue replacement in an organ, causing potential structural or functional changes. Radiologically characterized by increased density and architectural distortion.

name: Focal Nodular Hyperplasia
definition: Benign liver lesion composed of regenerative nodules with distinct vascular pattern. Radiologically characterized by specific enhancement patterns on contrast studies.

name: Focal Nodular Hyperplasia (FNH)
definition: A benign liver lesion characterized by hyperplastic nodules of hepatic tissue with a central stellate scar. On imaging, it appears as a well-defined, homogeneous mass with central scar and characteristic arterial phase enhancement.

name: Focal orchitis
definition: Inflammatory condition of the testicle characterized by localized swelling and inflammation in a specific region. On radiology, typically appears as a focal area of increased echogenicity or signal intensity.

name: Follicular adenoma
definition: A benign thyroid tumor arising from follicular cells, typically appearing as a well-circumscribed, homogeneous nodule on imaging studies. Often detected incidentally during thyroid ultrasound or CT examinations.

name: Follicular Cyst
definition: A fluid-filled sac developing within a follicular structure, commonly seen in ovaries. On imaging, appears as a thin-walled, round or oval cystic lesion with clear fluid contents.

name: Follicular Thyroid Carcinoma
definition: A malignant thyroid neoplasm originating from follicular cells, characterized by encapsulated growth and potential for metastasis. On imaging, appears as a solid or partially cystic nodule with variable enhancement patterns.

name: Foramen of Winslow Hernia
definition: A rare type of internal hernia occurring through the epiploic foramen (Winslow's foramen) into the lesser sac. Radiologically identified through cross-sectional imaging showing bowel herniation through this specific anatomical space.

name: Foraminal Stenosis
definition: Narrowing of the neural foramen where spinal nerve roots exit, typically caused by degenerative changes or disc herniation. Radiologically characterized by reduced foraminal diameter and potential nerve root compression.

name: Foreign bodies
definition: Any external object inadvertently introduced into the body, detectable through various imaging modalities. Radiographic techniques help locate, characterize, and guide potential removal strategies.

name: Foreign body
definition: A radiographic finding of an object or material present in a body cavity or tissue that is not naturally occurring, detectable through various imaging modalities.

name: Foreign body aspiration
definition: Accidental inhalation of an external object into the respiratory tract, potentially causing airway obstruction. Chest radiographs and CT scans can help identify location and characteristics of aspirated material.

name: Foreign Body Aspiration (FBA)
definition: Accidental inhalation of an external object into the respiratory tract, potentially causing airway obstruction. Chest radiographs and CT scans can help identify location and characteristics of aspirated material.

name: Fournier Gangrene
definition: A rare, rapidly progressive necrotizing soft tissue infection of the external genitalia and perineal region. Imaging studies like CT can help assess extent of infection and identify gas formation.

name: Fracture
definition: A break in bone continuity, detectable through various radiographic techniques including X-ray, CT, and MRI. Imaging helps determine fracture type, location, and potential treatment approach.

name: Fracture (Periprosthetic)
definition: A bone break occurring around a prosthetic implant, typically assessed through specialized radiographic techniques to evaluate implant integrity and potential surgical intervention.

name: Fractures
definition: Breaks in bone continuity, detectable through various radiographic techniques including X-ray, CT, and MRI. Imaging helps determine fracture types, locations, and potential treatment approaches.

name: Fragility Fractures
definition: Bone breaks occurring in individuals with reduced bone density, typically in older populations, often associated with minimal trauma. Radiographic techniques help assess bone quality and fracture characteristics.

name: Frontal Lesion
definition: A pathological area or abnormality located in the frontal region of the brain, typically identified through neuroimaging techniques like CT or MRI. These lesions can represent various conditions such as tumors, infarcts, or inflammatory processes.

name: Frontotemporal Dementia
definition: A neurodegenerative disorder characterized by progressive changes in behavior, personality, and language, typically identified through brain imaging showing frontal and temporal lobe atrophy.

name: Frontotemporal Dementia (FTD)
definition: A neurodegenerative disorder characterized by progressive changes in behavior, personality, and language, typically identified through brain imaging showing frontal and temporal lobe atrophy.

name: Functional constipation
definition: A chronic disorder of bowel habits characterized by infrequent or difficult bowel movements, typically evaluated through abdominal imaging to rule out structural causes.

name: Functional disorders
definition: Medical conditions where symptoms cannot be fully explained by structural abnormalities, often requiring comprehensive imaging to exclude organic pathology.

name: fundoscopic exam
definition: Fundoscopic examination is an ophthalmological procedure that involves examining the posterior segment of the eye, including the retina, optic disc, blood vessels, and underlying tissues using specialized optical instruments.

name: Fungal infections
definition: Pathological conditions caused by fungal organisms, detectable through various imaging modalities like X-ray, CT, and MRI depending on the affected organ system.

name: Fungal meningitis
definition: An inflammatory condition of the meninges caused by fungal pathogens, typically diagnosed through neuroimaging and cerebrospinal fluid analysis.

name: Fungal pneumonia
definition: A lung infection caused by fungal organisms, characterized by specific radiographic findings on chest X-ray or CT scan showing infiltrates, consolidation, or nodular patterns.

name: Fungal Sinusitis
definition: An inflammatory condition of the paranasal sinuses caused by fungal growth, identifiable through CT or MRI showing characteristic sinus opacification and soft tissue changes.

name: Fungus ball
definition: A localized collection of fungal material within a body cavity or organ, often appearing as a dense, well-defined mass on imaging studies.

name: Ga-68 DOTATATE (PET/CT)
definition: Ga-68 DOTATATE PET/CT is a specialized molecular imaging technique using gallium-68 labeled somatostatin analog for detecting neuroendocrine tumors. It provides high-resolution metabolic and anatomical imaging with excellent sensitivity for neuroendocrine pathologies.

name: Ga-68 DOTATATE PET/CT
definition: Ga-68 DOTATATE PET/CT is a specialized molecular imaging technique using gallium-68 labeled somatostatin analog for detecting neuroendocrine tumors. It provides high-resolution metabolic and anatomical imaging with excellent sensitivity for neuroendocrine pathologies.

name: Gadolinium Deposition
definition: Accumulation of gadolinium contrast agent in body tissues, particularly in the brain, detectable through specialized MRI sequences and potentially causing signal intensity changes.

name: Galactocele
definition: A benign breast cyst filled with milk-like fluid, typically identified through ultrasound or mammographic imaging as a well-defined, smooth-bordered lesion.

name: Galactography
definition: Galactography is a specialized radiographic technique used to image the milk ducts of the breast using contrast material. It is primarily used to investigate nipple discharge and identify potential ductal abnormalities.

name: Galactorrhea
definition: Inappropriate milk production not related to childbirth or breastfeeding, potentially associated with hormonal changes or pituitary disorders, often evaluated through imaging of the breast and endocrine system.

name: Galaxy sign
definition: A radiographic sign characterized by a complex, swirling configuration resembling a galaxy, typically seen in specific imaging studies.

name: Galeazzi fracture
definition: A specific type of fracture involving the radius and ulna, typically assessed through radiographic imaging to determine the extent and alignment of bone displacement.

name: Gallbladder adenoma
definition: A benign tumor of the gallbladder mucosa, typically discovered incidentally during abdominal imaging studies like ultrasound or CT scan.

name: Gallbladder Cancer
definition: A rare and aggressive malignant tumor originating in the gallbladder wall, typically detected through imaging techniques like CT, ultrasound, and MRI. Radiological findings often include wall thickening, irregular masses, and potential metastatic spread.

name: Gallbladder carcinoma
definition: A malignant neoplasm of the gallbladder characterized by abnormal cell growth within the gallbladder wall. Radiological evaluation helps in staging and determining the extent of tumor invasion.

name: Gallbladder Emphysema
definition: An uncommon condition involving air or gas within the gallbladder wall, typically detected through radiographic imaging. CT and X-ray can reveal characteristic gas patterns indicating potential underlying pathology.

name: Gallbladder pathology
definition: A comprehensive term describing various abnormalities and diseases affecting the gallbladder, detectable through multiple imaging modalities. Radiological techniques help identify structural, inflammatory, and neoplastic changes.

name: Gallbladder Perforation
definition: A serious condition where the gallbladder wall develops a breach or hole, allowing potential leakage of bile into the abdominal cavity. Radiological imaging is crucial for detecting and assessing the extent of perforation.

name: Gallbladder polyps
definition: Benign growths protruding from the gallbladder wall, typically identified during ultrasound or CT examinations. Radiological monitoring helps determine their size, characteristics, and potential malignant transformation risk.

name: Gallbladder sludge
definition: A mixture of particulate matter, mucus, and bile within the gallbladder, typically detected through ultrasound imaging. Radiological findings include echogenic material with dependent layering.

name: Gallstone ileus
definition: A rare mechanical small bowel obstruction caused by a large gallstone that has migrated into the intestinal tract. Radiological findings include pneumobilia and potential bowel obstruction signs.

name: Gallstone Pancreatitis
definition: An inflammatory condition of the pancreas triggered by gallstones obstructing pancreatic ducts. Radiological imaging helps assess pancreatic inflammation, necrosis, and potential complications.

name: Gallstones
definition: Solid, stone-like deposits formed in the gallbladder, typically composed of cholesterol or calcium bilirubinate. Radiological techniques like ultrasound and CT are primary methods for detection and characterization.

name: Ganglioglioma
definition: A rare, slow-growing brain tumor composed of neuronal and glial cells, typically detected through MRI and CT imaging. Radiological evaluation helps assess tumor location, size, and potential surgical intervention.

name: Ganglion Cyst
definition: A benign soft tissue tumor typically occurring near joints, most commonly on the wrist. Radiological imaging helps differentiate it from other soft tissue masses and assess its characteristics.

name: Gangrenous cholecystitis
definition: A severe form of gallbladder inflammation characterized by tissue death and potential gas formation. Radiological findings include wall thickening, gas within the gallbladder wall, and potential perforation.

name: Gardner Syndrome
definition: A rare genetic disorder characterized by multiple colorectal polyps and soft tissue tumors. Radiological imaging helps track polyp development and potential malignant transformation.

name: Garre's Sclerosing Osteomyelitis
definition: A rare chronic bone infection characterized by progressive bone sclerosis, typically affecting the mandible. Radiological findings include bone thickening, increased density, and potential periosteal reactions.

name: Gastric Adenocarcinoma
definition: Malignant epithelial tumor of the stomach mucosa, typically appearing as irregular thickening or mass on radiographic imaging. Commonly detected through CT, endoscopic ultrasound, or upper GI series.

name: Gastric cancer
definition: Malignant neoplasm originating in the stomach, characterized by abnormal cell growth and potential metastasis. Radiographic findings often include wall thickening, irregular masses, and potential lymph node involvement.

name: Gastric duplication cyst
definition: Rare congenital anomaly appearing as a fluid-filled cystic lesion adjacent to the stomach, typically identified on cross-sectional imaging like CT or MRI. Often asymptomatic but can cause complications if large.

name: Gastric Emphysema
definition: Rare condition characterized by gas within the gastric wall, typically seen on imaging as intramural gas tracking. Often associated with underlying mucosal injury or surgical complications.

name: Gastric leak
definition: Pathological condition where there is an abnormal opening or breach in the gastric wall, allowing gastric contents to leak. Radiographically detected through contrast studies or CT with oral/IV contrast.

name: Gastric Volvulus
definition: Abnormal twisting of the stomach around its mesenteric axis, potentially causing obstruction. Radiographic findings include abnormal stomach positioning and potential signs of bowel obstruction.

name: Gastrinoma
definition: Rare neuroendocrine tumor producing excessive gastrin, typically identified through cross-sectional imaging like CT or MRI. Often located in pancreas or duodenum.

name: Gastritis
definition: Inflammatory condition of the stomach lining, appearing on imaging as mucosal thickening or irregularity. Typically diagnosed through endoscopy and confirmed with radiographic studies.

name: Gastroenteritis
definition: Inflammatory condition of the gastrointestinal tract, characterized by acute inflammation of stomach and intestines. Radiographic findings may include bowel wall thickening and fluid collections.

name: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease (GERD)
definition: Chronic condition of acid reflux from stomach to esophagus, often visualized through barium swallow studies or endoscopic imaging. Characterized by abnormal lower esophageal sphincter function.

name: Gastrointestinal Bleeding (GI Bleeding)
definition: Hemorrhage within the gastrointestinal tract, detected through various radiographic techniques like CT angiography, nuclear medicine studies, or contrast-enhanced imaging.

name: Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST)
definition: Mesenchymal tumor of the gastrointestinal tract, typically appearing as a well-defined mass on CT or MRI. Often originates in the stomach or small intestine.

name: Gastroparesis
definition: Condition of delayed gastric emptying, characterized by impaired stomach motility. Radiographically diagnosed through nuclear medicine gastric emptying studies.

name: Gastroparesis (Delayed Gastric Emptying)
definition: Condition of delayed gastric emptying, characterized by impaired stomach motility. Radiographically diagnosed through nuclear medicine gastric emptying studies.

name: Gastroschisis
definition: Congenital abdominal wall defect where intestines protrude outside the body, typically diagnosed prenatally through ultrasound or confirmed postnatally through radiographic imaging.

name: General Pathology
definition: A branch of medical science studying disease processes and their mechanisms. In radiology, general pathology provides critical context for interpreting imaging findings and understanding disease progression.

name: Genetic disorders
definition: Disorders caused by variations or mutations in an individual's genetic material. In radiology, genetic disorders often manifest with specific structural or developmental abnormalities visible on imaging studies.

name: Genetic effects
definition: Changes or alterations in genetic material that can impact biological systems. In radiology, genetic effects may be observed through structural variations or developmental anomalies.

name: Genetic Pancreatitis
definition: A rare form of pancreatitis with a genetic basis. Radiological imaging can reveal characteristic pancreatic structural changes and potential complications.

name: Genetic syndromes (Marfan, Ehlers-Danlos)
definition: Inherited conditions characterized by specific genetic mutations affecting connective tissue. Radiology plays a crucial role in diagnosing and monitoring structural manifestations of these syndromes.

name: Genetic testing
definition: Genetic testing involves analyzing an individual's DNA to identify potential genetic variations, mutations, or inherited conditions. In radiology, it can help predict disease risk, guide personalized treatment, and understand genetic predispositions.

name: Geniculate Ganglion Fracture
definition: A rare fracture involving the geniculate ganglion, typically requiring detailed radiographic imaging for accurate diagnosis and assessment.

name: Germ Cell Tumor
definition: A tumor originating from reproductive cells, which can occur in various body locations. Radiological imaging is essential for identifying, characterizing, and staging these tumors.

name: Germinal matrix hemorrhage
definition: A type of brain hemorrhage occurring in premature infants within the germinal matrix region. Radiological techniques like cranial ultrasound are critical for detecting and grading these hemorrhages.

name: Germinal Matrix Hemorrhage (GMH)
definition: A specific type of brain hemorrhage in premature infants, characterized by bleeding within the germinal matrix. Radiological assessment helps determine severity and potential neurological implications.

name: Germinal Matrix Hemorrhage (Grade IV)
definition: The most severe classification of germinal matrix hemorrhage, involving extensive bleeding and potential brain parenchymal involvement. Advanced radiological techniques are crucial for accurate diagnosis.

name: Germinoma
definition: A rare type of germ cell tumor typically occurring in the central nervous system or reproductive organs. Radiological imaging is essential for precise localization and characterization.

name: Gestational Trophoblastic Disease
definition: A group of rare pregnancy-related tumors arising from placental tissue. Radiological imaging plays a critical role in diagnosis, staging, and monitoring treatment response.

name: Gestational Trophoblastic Disease (GTD)
definition: A spectrum of pregnancy-related tumoral conditions originating from placental tissue. Radiological techniques are fundamental in detecting and managing these complex conditions.

name: GI Perforations
definition: Holes or ruptures in the gastrointestinal tract wall, which can be life-threatening. Radiological imaging is crucial for detecting, localizing, and assessing the extent of these perforations.

name: Giant cell tumor
definition: A rare, typically benign tumor composed of multinucleated giant cells. Radiological imaging helps characterize the tumor's location, size, and potential impact on surrounding structures.

name: Giant Cell Tumor (GCT)
definition: A rare, aggressive bone tumor typically occurring at the end of long bones, characterized by locally destructive behavior and potential for malignant transformation. Radiologically appears as an eccentric, lytic lesion with minimal reactive sclerosis.

name: Giant Lacunes/Striatocapsular Infarcts (embolic source)
definition: Small, deep brain infarcts located in the basal ganglia and internal capsule regions, often associated with embolic stroke and microangiopathic disease. Radiologically appear as small, round or ovoid areas of signal change on MRI.

name: GIST
definition: Gastrointestinal stromal tumor, a rare mesenchymal neoplasm originating from the digestive tract's interstitial cells of Cajal. Radiologically appears as a heterogeneous mass with potential areas of necrosis and hemorrhage.

name: GIST tumor rupture with active bleeding
definition: A serious complication of GIST characterized by active hemorrhage from tumor rupture, appearing as heterogeneous mass with surrounding hemorrhagic changes and potential contrast extravasation on imaging studies.

name: Glandular Hyperplasia (4-gland disease)
definition: Abnormal proliferation of glandular tissue, often involving parathyroid or other endocrine glands. Radiologically characterized by enlarged, hyperplastic glandular structures with potential nodular or diffuse changes.

name: Glaucoma
definition: Optic nerve and retinal damage caused by increased intraocular pressure, leading to progressive visual field loss. Radiologically characterized by optic nerve head changes and potential structural alterations.

name: Glenohumeral instability
definition: Pathological condition involving abnormal movement and potential dislocation of the shoulder joint. Radiologically demonstrated through joint space changes, labral tears, and potential bone morphology alterations.

name: Glioblastoma
definition: Highly aggressive primary brain tumor with poor prognosis, characterized by rapid growth and infiltrative behavior. Radiologically appears as a heterogeneous, contrast-enhancing mass with central necrosis.

name: Glioblastoma (GBM)
definition: Highly aggressive primary brain tumor with poor prognosis, characterized by rapid growth and infiltrative behavior. Radiologically appears as a heterogeneous, contrast-enhancing mass with central necrosis.

name: Glioma
definition: Primary brain tumor originating from glial cells, with varying degrees of malignancy. Radiologically characterized by abnormal signal intensity, mass effect, and potential contrast enhancement.

name: Glioma (Brain Tumor)
